stiff.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if someone or a part of their body is stiff, their muscles hurt and it is difficult for them to move
stiff.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I never felt stiff after training until I was in my thirties.
The next morning I was as stiff as a board (=very stiff).
Alastair woke with a stiff neck.
Her legs were stiff from kneeling.
Her fingers were stiff with cold.
stiff.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: firm, hard, or difficult to bend
stiff.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: a shirt with a stiff collar
stiff.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a stiff mixture is thick and almost solid, so that it is not easy to mix
stiff.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Beat the egg whites until stiff.
stiff.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: difficult to do or deal with
stiff.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Graduates face stiff competition in getting jobs.
stiff.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a stiff punishment is great or severe

stiff.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: difficult to move, turn, or open
stiff.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Pull hard – that drawer’s very stiff.

stiff.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: a stiff price etc is high, especially higher than the price etc of similar things
stiff.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the body of a dead person
stiff.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: someone who you think is old-fashioned and too formal
stiff.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: His business tactics outraged the stiffs of the UK establishment.
stiff.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to cheat someone by not paying them, especially by not leaving a tip in a restaurant
